results.title: Love My Way: Crazy Love
results.creator_credit: Jessica Hobbs, Marissa Cooke, Jacquelin Perske, Claudia Karvan, John Edwards, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Showtime, Foxtel and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
The groundbreaking, multiple award-winning drama series ‘Love My Way’ was one of the first Australian productions made exclusively for subscription television (Foxtel). This enabled Foxtel to allow the producers ‘absolute creative freedom…to carve out a piece of TV drama that was edgy, daring, provocative’ (Foxtel’s Brian Walsh).

Revolving around the untidy lives and complicated loves of a contemporary Australian blended family and their friends, ‘Love My Way’ was both critically acclaimed and highly successful, with a further two seasons produced following the initial ten episodes of Series 1.

Series 1, Episode 3 first aired on Foxtel on 29th November, 2004.

results.title: Michael Connor: in conversation with Conrad Bodman
results.brief_description: Michael Connor, Consultant Curator of ‘Screen Worlds: The Story of Film, Television and Digital Culture’, is in conversation with Conrad Bodman, ACMI’s Head of Exhibitions. Connor discusses both the overall concept and the separate sections of the exhibition. Connor and Bodman discuss some of the challenges of choosing, sourcing and exhibiting over a hundred years of creative work and technology relating to the moving image.

results.title: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010
results.brief_description: Oscar winning animation director and writer Adam Elliot speaks candidly about his stop frame animation processes and, more importantly, about why he makes films. Adam also talks about the challenges he faced during the making of his first feature film ‘Mary and Max’.
results.title_for_label: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010

results.title: Interview with Christopher Doyle
results.brief_description:
Australian cinematographer Christopher Doyle talks about how time operates in his filmmaking, how life experience has shaped his work, the role of repetition, structure and movement in cinematogrpahy, how space informs and influences his technique, and about the collaborative process of filmmaking.
Includes clips from ‘Paranoid Park’ 2007; ‘Days of Being Wild’ (A Fei zheng chuan), 1990; ‘Happy Together’ (Chun gwong cha sit), 1997; ‘In the Mood for Love’ (Fa yeung nin wa), 2000; and ‘Fallen Angels’ (Duo luo tian shi), 1995.

results.title: Peach's Australia: Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Bill Peach, David Roberts and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Popular former ABC TV personality Bill Peach travels the length and breadth of Australia seeking out often little known facets of the country’s history and their relation to present day conditions in the particular areas.
In this episode, Bill Peach explores Arnhem Land and it’s history, as seen by the Aboriginal people who live there. The program was filmed at the Gove, Elcho Island, Deaf Adder Gorge, Murganella and other places within the Kakadu National Park and includes a visit to the oldest rock paintings in Australia.

results.title: Killers in Eden
results.creator_credit: Klaus Toft, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit, Granada International Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
‘Killers in Eden’ is the story of perhaps the most extraordinary partnership ever forged between humans and wild animals. Locals in the Australian town of Eden claim that beginning in the mid-1800s an intimate and co-operative relationship developed between human whalers and killer whales.

The giant prey whales - minke whales, humpbacks, right whales, blue whales - were herded into Twofold Bay by the killer whales. This allowed the shore-based human whalers to close in for the kill. Working together in Eden, man and beast were able to do something neither could have managed on their own; killing the largest whales on earth. The two hunters then shared the spoils through an arrangement known as the ‘Law of the Tongue’.

Whale enthusiast Greg Mckee, who has researched this story for 15 years, joins forces with eminent zoologist Danielle Clode to investigate the intimate details of the relationship. Together, Greg and Danielle reveal not only the fascinating details of how the partnership began, but also why it tragically ended. A Co-production with Granada International.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Klaus Toft, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit, Granada International Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Landline: Stripping the Myth
results.brief_description:
‘Landline’ is the ABC’s national rural issues program.

This episode investigates the conventionally accepted history of the invention and development of the combine harvester. The widely held belief that a young Victorian, Hugo Victor McKay, was the inventor of the world’s first such machine is exposed as a myth.

First broadcast on 13th March, 2005.

results.title: Mother and Son: Arthur's Night Out
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Atherden, Geoffrey Portmann and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
‘Mother and Son’ was an Australian television comedy series that centred on the relationship between the elderly Maggie Beare (Ruth Cracknell) and her carer son Arthur (Garry McDonald).

In this episode, Arthur’s attempts to enjoy a night out with his estranged wife, Deirdre (Suzanne Roylance) are derailed by Maggie’s determination not to be left out.

First broadcast on 6th February, 1984.
